Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Field-Based Quantification of Dehyration Flux from Subducting Lithologies, Syros and Sifnos, Greece
Award.AbstractNarration:
The release of water (and other volatiles) from subducted rocks represents an important part of the global geological water (and CO2) cycle. More specifically, it is a crucial triggering process for arc volcanism, seismicity, and the generation of ore forming fluids. Knowledge of the primary dehydration flux from subducted rocks as well as the timing and location (e.g. depth and temperature range) of this release is fundamental to understanding such broad tectonic processes, but rates of fluid production are currently generally poorly understood. The proposed research will employ novel methods to reconstruct dehydration fluxes from a 45 million year old subduction complex now exposed at the surface as well-preserved blueschist and eclogite rocks on the islands of Syros and Sifnos, Greece. With this unique information, geodynamic model predictions of subduction zone dehydration processes will be tested and refined.

A key question is whether the primary dehydration flux from subducted rocks is continuous or pulsed. While many past predictions suggest relatively continuous release of water from descending rocks, recent work (including preliminary work on Sifnos) has suggested that metamorphic reactions during subduction can occur in brief bursts that rapidly liberate water. Concentrically zoned garnet crystals, which grow during subduction zone dehydration, will be dated like tree rings with the Samarium-Neodymium decay system. Crucially, the dating resolution will be sufficient to resolve changes in the rate of garnet growth (i.e. pulses) as short as a few hundred thousand years. Thermodynamic analysis will provide constraints on the specific depth and temperature interval of garnet growth, which will be linked directly to concomitant water release for each rock. Constraints from thermodynamic analysis will be integrated with direct rate & age information from zoned garnet geochronology to provide a unique dehydration chronology. These novel methods and resulting datasets will provide scientists a new window into subduction zone processes occurring deep within the Earth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Subduction of rocks at destructive tectonic plate boundaries results in the release of volatiles such as CO2 and H2O through processes that are intimately linked to the genesis of arc volcanoes and major earthquakes, to chemical transport through Earth, and to the slab densification which drives tectonic plate motion. We can gain an improved understanding of these processes through knowledge of the depth and temperature, rates, and mechanisms of the chemical reactions that drive this devolatilization. In this research, we have reconstructed dehydration fluxes of rocks that experienced subduction ~50 million years ago and were subsequently exhumed to Earth?s surface, now constituting part of the Greek island of Syros. In collaboration with scientists from Boston University and Boston College, we collected samples of these rocks in 2014, also gaining access to their archive of samples collected previously from the nearby island of Sifnos. PI Caddick and the Virginia Tech (VT) participants undertook thermodynamic analysis of these samples, with the aim of constraining the depth?temperature conditions over which the growth of specific hydrous and anhydrous minerals occurred. The Boston team led efforts to date the growth of garnet within these rocks accurately. Garnet was targeted because it is one of the most important products of mineral dehydration reactions in subduction settings. Together, our results suggest that garnet growth occurred over at least eight million years (~52 ? 44 million years ago), but that discrete pulses of syn-devolatilization growth appear to have occurred within this interval. Unusually, some of our samples record good evidence for mineral growth during the early phases of their exhumation, revealing the production of a relatively substantial amount of water (several weight percent) as rocks began their ascent towards the surface. Furthermore, thermodynamic modeling has constrained some of the consequences of this dehydration in terms of CO2 generation, quantifying how H2O-rich fluids produced in one lithology will interact with the rocks that they then pass through and will drive decarbonation of these rocks.

In addition to initiating a productive collaboration between PIs at Virginia Tech and Boston College, this grant supported the education of several students. The VT and BU/BC participants worked closely together, with joint fieldwork, numerous group meetings, and student exchange visits. This resulted in collaborative, student-led conference presentations that involved multiple students from each institution. The grant supported one VT Ph.D. student focused on thermodynamic modeling of subducting rocks and several undergraduate students working on the nature of fluids in subduction settings. We have published the work of two of these undergraduate participants in peer-reviewed journals, and several additional publications are in review or preparation. Products from this grant have been incorporated into undergraduate teaching at Virginia Tech and have been shared in public outreach talks and through the Virginia Tech Museum of Geosciences.
